name: Horses for Courses - Idiomatically Speaking! Online Quiz | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: To perform a series of tasks in the wrong order is to do what?
questions.correct: Put the cart before the horse
options: Put the horse before the cart
Look a gift horse in the mouth
questions.explanation:
Put the cart before the horse.

	If you decide what to wear before you've even been invited to a party you could be accused of putting the cart before the horse, don't you agree?

questions.text: A circumstance or a topic that is very different from what you had first thought it would be, is what?
questions.correct: A horse of a different colour
options: Shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted
questions.explanation:
A horse of a different colour.

	If you said you didn't like going to the movies just because you couldn't afford it, well, that's a horse of a different colour!

questions.text: If someone gets angry about a particular subject and starts criticising other people just because they think they are better or more clever, they are said to be doing what?
options: Looking a gift horse in the mouth
questions.explanation:
Getting on their high horse.

	A good example would be rabbiting on against single parents.  You can't force people to get married and as such you'd be getting on your high horse!

questions.text: Wasting time trying to achieve something that you know will not succeed is said to be doing what?
questions.explanation:
Flogging a dead horse.

	You'd be flogging a dead horse trying to persuade someone who really hates to travel to go overseas, even for a holiday!

questions.text: If you get information from someone who is directly involved in something and therefore knows a lot about it, you are said to be doing what?
questions.correct: Getting it straight from the horse's mouth
options: Shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted
questions.explanation:
Getting it straight from the horse's mouth.

	If someone assures you that so-and-so has handed in their resignation at work and they say they got it straight from the horse's mouth means they were told by the resignee, so they believe it must be true!

questions.text: If you consume a lot at a meal, you are said to do what?
questions.explanation:
Eat like a horse.

	Eating like a horse means you always eat a lot of food - "She eats like a horse, so I don't know how she manages to stay so thin!" If you are very hungry, you might say, "I could eat a horse!" -- but not that you are eating one. Another expression with a similar meaning is to say that one eats like a pig.

questions.text: Giving someone every opportunity to do something, but not being able to force them to do it if they don't really want to, is said to be doing what?
options: Shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted
questions.explanation:
Leading a horse to water.

	If you made travel arrangements, bought tickets and even took someone to the airport, but they just wouldn't get on the plane would be leading a horse to water, and furthermore, not being able to make them drink!

questions.text: If you're very hungry you could do what?
questions.explanation:
Eat a horse.

	If you've eaten nothing all day - you could probably eat a horse, and in some countries they actually do still eat horses!

questions.text: If you criticise something or feel doubtful about something that is really a good chance or offer, you are said to be doing what?
questions.correct: Looking a gift horse in the mouth
options: Putting the cart before the horse
questions.explanation:
Looking a gift horse in the mouth.

	If someone tells you not to look a gift horse in the mouth, they mean that whatever chance you've been given or whatever you've been offered may not necessarily be the answer to your prayers but it would be a darn sight better than nothing!

questions.text: Trying to stop something from happening when it has actually already happened and cannot be changed, is said to be like doing what?
questions.correct: Shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted
questions.explanation:
Shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted.

	Pumping up your security after a major theft would seem to be a bit like shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted!  (with thanks for all definitions to the Cambridge International Dictionary of Idioms!)
